rag_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from entering into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement with a Retail Client. This restriction is clearly outlined in the regulatory framework to protect the interests of Retail Clients, who may not have the same level of financial sophistication as Professional Clients. The rule is explicitly stated in Rule 15.11.A.1, which mandates that an Authorised Person must not engage in such agreements concerning assets belonging to Retail Clients [#P:45762c70-0a0b-47e4-9db7-e70b9924abeb]. Additionally, the guidance provided under Rule 14.3.2 reinforces this prohibition, emphasizing that Title Transfer Collateral Agreements are not permissible with Retail Clients [#P:f8d4b63b-c965-42c6-abf2-f70dfb84afaa]. This regulatory stance ensures that Retail Clients' assets are safeguarded from the complexities and risks associated with Title Transfer Collateral Agreements, which are more suitable for Professional Clients who are better equipped to understand and manage such financial arrangements. There are no exceptions to this rule mentioned in the provided context, underscoring the absolute nature of this prohibition.

question: When does money received under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client fall outside the scope of the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules?
gold_answer: The Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules do not apply when money is received under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client. This is because such money is not considered Client Money under the applicable definition. The rules specifically exclude the application of these regulations to Safe Custody Assets or Client Money held by an Authorised Person in the context of a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement. Therefore, when an Authorised Person holds money under these conditions, the usual protections and requirements of the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules are not triggered. This regulatory framework ensures that certain financial transactions, particularly those involving Professional Clients and specific collateral agreements, are treated differently to reflect the nature of the agreements and the parties involved [#SRC:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc] and [#TGT:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7].
rag_answer: Money received under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement from a Professional Client falls outside the scope of the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules when it is held by an Authorised Person pursuant to such an agreement. This is explicitly stated in the regulations, which clarify that the Client Money Rules and Safe Custody Rules do not apply to Safe Custody Assets or Client Money held under a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement [#P:d541bbc2-9a05-45ff-8063-6dd671feecb7]. Additionally, it is important to note that money received under this type of agreement from a Professional Client is not considered Client Money [#P:875ef4dc-f3c8-464c-b6f3-6216b864e3bc]. This distinction is crucial because it delineates the regulatory obligations of the Authorised Person, ensuring that such funds are treated differently from typical Client Money, which must otherwise remain in a Client Account until certain conditions are met [#P:385a7557-f9e5-4b07-a74c-708290be41b7]. It is also worth mentioning that an Authorised Person is prohibited from entering into a Title Transfer Collateral Agreement with a Retail Client, which underscores the specific applicability of these rules to Professional Clients only [#P:f8d4b63b-c965-42c6-abf2-f70dfb84afaa].

Therefore, when dealing with Professional Clients under such agreements, the usual obligations and protections associated with Client Money and Safe Custody do not apply, streamlining the handling of these funds for the Authorised Person.

question: Under what conditions is an Authorised Person prohibited from using a Client's Safe Custody Assets for staking purposes?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from using a Client's Safe Custody Assets for the purpose of staking unless they have obtained the Client's prior written permission. The Regulator considers the use of Virtual Assets for staking as a use for the purposes of the Authorised Person, which falls under the restriction against using Client assets for the Authorised Person's own purpose or that of another Person without explicit consent. This prohibition ensures that the interests of the Client are protected and that their assets are not used in a manner that benefits the Authorised Person or another party without the Client's informed agreement. Therefore, compliance with this requirement is essential to avoid regulatory breaches and to maintain trust in the management of Client assets [#SRC:ee60daeb-c185-4221-bf81-7a1bbeb8badc] and [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098].
rag_answer: An Authorised Person is prohibited from using a Client's Safe Custody Assets for staking purposes unless specific conditions are met. Firstly, the Authorised Person must obtain the Client's prior written permission before using their Safe Custody Assets for any purpose, including staking. This is a fundamental requirement to ensure that the Client is aware of and consents to the use of their assets in such activities [#P:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must have systems and controls in place to ensure that adequate records are maintained to protect the Safe Custody Assets used for such purposes. This includes ensuring that equivalent assets are returned to the Client Account and that the Client is not disadvantaged by the use of their Safe Custody Assets [#P:82a79456-0923-48f0-8521-17b43774e939]. These measures are crucial to safeguard the Client's interests and maintain the integrity of the custody services provided. Failure to adhere to these conditions would result in a prohibition on using the Client's Safe Custody Assets for staking or any other similar purposes.

question: What should an Authorised Person do to properly handle a Client's Safe Custody Assets and keep the right records?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person must not use a Client's Safe Custody Assets for its own benefit or for someone else unless they have the Client's written permission first. This rule is important to protect the Client's assets and maintain trust. Additionally, the Authorised Person must keep proper records, including the Client's written permission, in their Resolution Pack when they are doing Investment Business. This pack should also have records about Client classification, agreements, and lists of Client Accounts. Keeping these records helps ensure that everything is in order for any checks or reviews by regulators. By following these rules, the Authorised Person shows they are handling Client assets responsibly and meeting regulatory requirements [#TGT:788b8b33-8176-4f23-8f1a-e6eab9427098] and [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].
rag_answer: To properly handle a Client's Safe Custody Assets and maintain appropriate records, an Authorised Person must adhere to several key obligations. Firstly, if the Authorised Person intends to use a Client's Safe Custody Assets for its own purposes or those of another, it must obtain the Client's prior written permission and ensure that adequate records are maintained to protect these assets, especially when used as collateral or for stock lending activities [#P:82a79456-0923-48f0-8521-17b43774e939]. Additionally, the Authorised Person must reconcile its records of Client Accounts with statements from Third Party Agents at least monthly, and conduct a physical count and reconciliation of Safe Custody Assets at least every six months [#P:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6]. Furthermore, the Authorised Person is required to send regular statements to its Clients, with the frequency depending on whether the Client is Retail or Professional [#P:c8d90cd9-2076-4aad-a6ae-6d57990ba0f8]. Lastly, the Authorised Person must ensure that its Auditor provides a Safe Custody Auditor's Report, confirming compliance with Safe Custody Rules and identifying any discrepancies [#P:99e42871-85c3-4bd8-8cea-8366dc6a7607]. These measures collectively ensure the integrity and proper management of Client Safe Custody Assets.

question: What must an Authorised Person do before placing a Safe Custody Investment with a Third Party Agent, considering the need for an assessment of appropriateness?
gold_answer: Before an Authorised Person places a Safe Custody Investment with a Third Party Agent or arranges custody through such an agent, it must undertake an assessment of the Third Party Agent. This assessment should conclude on reasonable grounds that the Third Party Agent is suitable to hold the Safe Custody Assets. Additionally, the Authorised Person must ensure that systems and controls are in place to maintain the suitability of the Third Party Agent over time. This includes ensuring that the Third Party Agent will provide protections equivalent to those required by the relevant regulations. Furthermore, the assessment of appropriateness of the Third Party Agent must be included in the Resolution Pack of the Authorised Person conducting Investment Business, as required [#TGT:11a7f665-04c0-4da8-b0ef-d75a9076ba43] and permitted [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].
rag_answer:
Before an Authorised Person places a Safe Custody Investment with a Third Party Agent, it must ensure the appropriateness of the Third Party Agent through a structured assessment process. This involves several key steps to ensure compliance and safeguard client assets. 

- The Authorised Person must undertake an assessment of the Third Party Agent and conclude on reasonable grounds that the agent is suitable to hold the Safe Custody Assets. [#P:11a7f665-04c0-4da8-b0ef-d75a9076ba43]
- It must have systems and controls in place to ensure that the Third Party Agent remains suitable over time. [#P:11a7f665-04c0-4da8-b0ef-d75a9076ba43]
- The Authorised Person must ensure that the Third Party Agent will provide protections equivalent to those conferred in the relevant section of the regulations. [#P:11a7f665-04c0-4da8-b0ef-d75a9076ba43]
- Additionally, before passing Safe Custody Assets to the Third Party Agent, the Authorised Person must procure a written acknowledgment from the agent, confirming specific conditions about account management and asset protection. [#P:57e8f079-f256-41f4-b1d3-fcbba0690a98]

These steps are crucial to ensure that the Third Party Agent is capable of safeguarding the investments and maintaining compliance with regulatory requirements.

question: What should an Authorised Person do before using a Third Party Agent for Safe Custody Investments, considering the need to assess if the agent is appropriate?
gold_answer: Before using a Third Party Agent for Safe Custody Investments, an Authorised Person must assess whether the agent is appropriate and suitable to hold those assets. This means they need to check and conclude that the Third Party Agent can safely manage the investments. They also need to have systems in place to make sure the agent stays suitable over time. The Third Party Agent must offer protections that are as good as those required by the regulations. Additionally, the assessment of the Third Party Agent's appropriateness must be recorded in the Authorised Person's Resolution Pack, which is a requirement for those conducting Investment Business [#TGT:11a7f665-04c0-4da8-b0ef-d75a9076ba43] and must be included [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5].

Additionally, the Authorised Person must have systems and controls in place to continuously monitor and ensure the ongoing suitability of the Third Party Agent [#P:11a7f665-04c0-4da8-b0ef-d75a9076ba43]. These steps ensure that the Third Party Agent is not only suitable at the outset but remains compliant with the necessary standards throughout the relationship.

question: What obligations must an Authorised Person fulfill regarding the assessment of a Third Party Agent's appropriateness before passing Safe Custody Assets, and what records must be maintained in the Resolution Pack?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to conduct an assessment of the appropriateness of a Third Party Agent before passing Safe Custody Assets to them. This involves obtaining a written acknowledgement from the Third Party Agent that confirms several key points, such as the distinct title of the account, the handling of Client Investments, and the separation of Client Investments from the Third Party Agent's assets. Additionally, the Third Party Agent must agree to provide statements detailing the Client Investments deposited. question: What is the frequency requirement for an Authorised Person to send statements to a Retail Client when providing custody of Virtual Assets, and how does this differ from the general requirement for Safe Custody Assets?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person that provides custody of Virtual Assets must send statements to a Retail Client at least monthly. However, for Virtual Assets, the requirement is specifically adjusted to a monthly frequency to ensure more regular updates to Retail Clients [#P:5b7dc83f-010b-4f5e-8eb9-e928d151c11e]. question: What actions must an Authorised Person take regarding the most recent reconciliations of Client Money to ensure compliance with both the Resolution Pack requirements and monthly reconciliation obligations with Third Party Agents?
gold_answer: An Authorised Person is required to maintain the most recent reconciliations of Client Money as part of their Resolution Pack, ensuring these records are up-to-date and comprehensive. This involves reconciling their records of Client Accounts with the monthly statements received from Third Party Agents at least once every calendar month. This dual obligation ensures that the Authorised Person not only keeps accurate and current records of Client Money but also aligns these records with external confirmations from Third Party Agents. By doing so, the Authorised Person fulfills the regulatory requirement to include these reconciliations in the Resolution Pack, thereby demonstrating compliance with both internal and external reconciliation standards. This process is crucial for maintaining the integrity and accuracy of financial records related to Client Money, which is essential for regulatory compliance and financial transparency [#SRC:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5] and [#TGT:99a621ce-b3ab-4dbc-a9c7-eac1065776e6].

This reconciliation process ensures that the records accurately reflect the actual balances and transactions, thereby maintaining the integrity of Client Money management. Additionally, the most recent reconciliations of Client Money must be included in the Resolution Pack, as stipulated by Rule 14.11.1 [#P:803ff2b9-9528-459a-b9d2-45066785e9f5]. The Resolution Pack should also contain a master document that allows for the retrieval of each document within the pack, ensuring that the reconciliations are easily accessible and verifiable [#P:9a2f70fe-ca63-4b72-a573-f428b37a1a24]. By adhering to these procedures, the Authorised Person not only complies with regulatory requirements but also enhances the transparency and reliability of its financial operations.

question: What are the specific reconciliation requirements for an Authorised Person providing custody in relation to Accepted Spot Commodities, and how do these differ from the general obligations for reconciling Client Accounts with Third Party Agents?

question: What must the individual referred to in the relevant rule provide after a reconciliation, and who must review this reconciliation?

question: What does a PFP Operator need to do to keep records of due diligence before publishing a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator needs to keep records of due diligence for at least six years. This includes all disclosures and documents related to the PFP Client and any Body Corporate involved. Before publishing a financing proposal, the Operator must check the PFP Prospect's management details, including the directors' and key officers' backgrounds. They also need to look at the PFP Prospect's financial health and regulatory status. The financing proposal itself must be checked to make sure it's clear, fair, and not misleading. These checks help meet disclosure rules and ensure everything is properly documented [#SRC:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7] and [#TGT:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce].

The PFP Operator must then maintain records of this due diligence for a minimum of six years [#P:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. This record-keeping obligation includes all disclosures made in accordance with the relevant rules, documentation between PFP Clients, any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator, and the PFP Prospect, as well as the due diligence itself [#P:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7]. By following these procedures, the PFP Operator ensures compliance with regulatory requirements and maintains transparency and accountability in its operations.

question: What due diligence actions must a PFP Operator undertake before publishing a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect, and what information must be made available to PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator is required to conduct thorough due diligence on a PFP Prospect before publishing any financing proposal on a Private Financing Platform. This due diligence must include an examination of the management's background, the financial soundness and regulatory status of the PFP Prospect, and the content of the financing proposal to ensure it is clear and not misleading. Concurrently, the PFP Operator must ensure that specific information is accessible to PFP Clients on the platform. This includes a statement of risks involved, confirmation that no credit or investment advice is provided, and advice for clients to seek independent counsel. Additionally, the platform must disclose the terms of operation, potential conflicts of interest, details of any Eligible Custodian, wind-down arrangements, and the methodology for due diligence, among other critical details. These requirements ensure transparency and protect the interests of all parties involved in the financing process [#SRC:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce] and [#TGT:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f].
rag_answer: Before publishing a financing proposal for a PFP Prospect, a PFP Operator must conduct thorough due diligence to meet disclosure requirements. This includes reviewing the management's details and background, assessing the fitness and propriety of directors and key officers, evaluating the PFP Prospect's financial soundness, good standing, and regulatory status, and ensuring the financing proposal is adequate, clear, fair, and not misleading [#P:1cdb958a-ff43-4d15-9ac0-0037381614ce]. Additionally, the PFP Operator must make specific information available to PFP Clients on the Private Financing Platform. This includes a statement of risks involved, confirmation that no credit or investment advice is provided, terms of operation, potential conflicts of interest, details of any Eligible Custodian, wind-down arrangements, financing proposal details, criteria for accepting proposals, due diligence methodology, governance of any intermediary Body Corporate, exit facility details, and any other relevant information [#P:1539edbe-2c5c-412f-8872-f359c291a27f]. The PFP Operator must also ensure that this information is updated to reflect any material changes and notify PFP Clients within a reasonable timeframe [#P:40149b11-dcb8-48a6-ab09-8d8c37923183]. Records of all disclosures and due diligence must be maintained for at least six years [#P:94d5a3fb-7438-42dd-8c48-70588f3d0dd7].

question: What records must a PFP Operator maintain for at least six years, and what information must be published on the Private Financing Platform to ensure compliance with obligations to PFP Clients?
gold_answer: A PFP Operator is required to maintain and keep a record of all disclosures made in accordance with specific rules, documentation between PFP Clients and any Body Corporate established by the PFP Operator, and due diligence undertaken, for a minimum of six years. question: Under what conditions may a Payment Service User and a Payment Service Provider agree in writing that certain rules, including those related to the withdrawal of consent, do not apply?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User that is not a Natural Person and a Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that specific rules, such as those concerning the withdrawal of consent, do not apply. This agreement can include rules related to charges for information, evidence on authentication and execution, and liability for unauthorized transactions, among others. Specifically, the withdrawal of consent is addressed in Rule 19.10.1, which can be excluded from application if both parties agree. Additionally, the Payer retains the right to withdraw consent for an individual Payment Transaction at any time before the Payment Order becomes irrevocable under Rule 19.14.3. This flexibility allows the parties to tailor their contractual obligations and rights, ensuring that the regulatory framework accommodates their specific needs and circumstances [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] and [#TGT:31fb705e-a65c-4024-99d4-fadfe13f8f32].
rag_answer: A Payment Service User and a Payment Service Provider may agree in writing that certain rules, including those related to the withdrawal of consent, do not apply when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person. This agreement allows them to opt out of specific regulatory requirements, providing flexibility in their contractual relationship. The key precondition is that the Payment Service User must be a legal entity rather than an individual. The rules that can be excluded by mutual agreement include those related to charges for information, withdrawal of consent, evidence on authentication and execution, liability for unauthorized transactions, requests for refunds, revocation of a Payment Order, and liability for charges. Additionally, the parties may agree on a different time period for addressing unauthorized or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions. This arrangement must be documented in writing to ensure clarity and mutual understanding between the parties involved. Such agreements are designed to tailor the regulatory framework to better suit the needs of non-natural persons engaging in payment services, allowing for more customized and potentially streamlined operations. [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] [#P:a0213781-cf1e-47ae-befc-8e10afd8e60d]

question: When can a Payment Service User and Provider agree that some rules, like those about withdrawing consent, don't apply?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User, if not a Natural Person, and a Payment Service Provider can agree in writing that certain rules, including those about withdrawing consent, don't apply to them. This means they can decide not to follow rules about charges for information, evidence on authentication, and liability for unauthorized transactions, among others. Specifically, they can agree not to follow Rule 19.10.1, which deals with withdrawing consent. However, the Payer can still withdraw consent for a Payment Transaction anytime before the Payment Order can't be revoked anymore, as stated in Rule 19.14.3. [#P:95fa60a1] Additionally, the parties may agree on a different time period concerning unauthorized or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions. question: Under what conditions may a Payment Service User and a Payment Service Provider agree to exclude certain rules, and how does this affect the procedure for withdrawing consent to a series of Payment Transactions?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User, when not a Natural Person, and a Payment Service Provider may mutually agree in writing to exclude specific rules, including those related to the withdrawal of consent for a series of Payment Transactions. This agreement allows them to bypass the standard rules that would otherwise apply to the withdrawal of consent, such as those concerning the time limits for revocation. Consequently, the Payer retains the ability to withdraw consent at any time, impacting future transactions by rendering them unauthorised. This procedural flexibility is contingent upon the mutual written agreement between the parties, which must explicitly state the exclusion of the relevant rules. Such an arrangement provides a tailored approach to managing consent and its withdrawal, aligning with the specific needs of the Payment Service User and Provider, while ensuring compliance with overarching regulatory frameworks [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] and [#TGT:d61bf1d0-40f9-4af1-89ee-04c9e0ae8a9f].

This agreement can affect the procedure for withdrawing consent to a series of Payment Transactions. Specifically, they may agree that Rule 19.10.1(3) and (4), which pertains to the withdrawal of consent, does not apply. [#P:95fa60a1] This means that the standard procedure for withdrawing consent, which would typically be included in a Framework Contract, can be altered or excluded by mutual agreement. The Framework Contract must otherwise include detailed information about the Payment Service Provider, the Payment Service, charges, communication, safeguards, corrective measures, changes, termination, redress, and, if applicable, the redemption of Stored Value. [#P:08c0ad25] By agreeing to exclude certain rules, the parties can customize their contractual obligations and procedures, including those related to consent withdrawal, to better suit their specific needs and circumstances. This flexibility allows for tailored agreements that can deviate from the standard regulatory framework, provided both parties consent in writing.

question: When can a Payment Service User and Provider agree to ignore some rules, and what happens to the process of stopping consent for future payments?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User, if not a Natural Person, and a Payment Service Provider can agree in writing to ignore certain rules, including those about stopping consent for future payments. This means they can choose not to follow the usual rules about how and when consent can be withdrawn. If they agree to this, the Payer can stop consent for a series of payments at any time, making future payments unauthorised. This agreement must be clearly written and agreed upon by both parties, allowing them to manage consent in a way that suits their specific needs. This flexibility helps them handle consent and its withdrawal effectively, while still following the main regulatory guidelines [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] and [#TGT:d61bf1d0-40f9-4af1-89ee-04c9e0ae8a9f].

Additionally, they may agree on a different time period for addressing unauthorized or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions [#P:95fa60a1]. Regarding the process of stopping consent for future payments, Rule 19.10.1(3) outlines the procedure for withdrawing consent, which must be included in the Framework Contract unless otherwise agreed in writing [#P:08c0ad25]. This means that if the parties agree to ignore Rule 19.10.1(3), the standard procedure for withdrawing consent may not apply, and they must establish an alternative method in their agreement. It is crucial that any such agreements are clearly documented to ensure both parties understand their rights and obligations.

question: Under what conditions may parties agree that certain notification rules do not apply, and what must the Payment Service Provider ensure regarding user notifications?
gold_answer: Parties may agree that specific rules concerning notification of loss or theft do not apply if a Low Value Payment Instrument cannot be stopped or its use prevented. However, the Payment Service Provider is obligated to ensure that appropriate means are always available for a Payment Service User to notify them of any loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorized use of the Payment Instrument. This ensures that even if certain rules are waived by agreement, the provider still maintains a system for users to report issues, thereby safeguarding against potential misuse or unauthorized transactions. The dual framework allows for flexibility in agreements while maintaining a baseline of security and user protection as required [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a] and permitted [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9].
rag_answer: Parties may agree that certain notification rules do not apply under specific conditions, particularly when dealing with Low Value Payment Instruments that do not allow for stopping or preventing their use. In such cases, the rules regarding notification of loss of the Payment Instrument and the Payer's liability for certain losses may be excluded by mutual agreement [#P:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9]. Additionally, when the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the parties can agree in writing to exclude several rules, including those related to charges for information, withdrawal of consent, and liability for unauthorised transactions, among others [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. The Payment Service Provider must ensure that the Framework Contract includes detailed information about the communication means agreed upon for transmitting information or notifications, including any technical requirements for the Payment Service User’s equipment and software [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. This ensures that the Payment Service User is adequately informed and can effectively manage their obligations and rights under the contract.

question: When can parties agree not to follow some rules about stopping a payment instrument, and what must the Payment Service Provider do for user notifications?
gold_answer: Parties can agree not to follow certain rules about notifying the loss or theft of a payment instrument if the instrument is a Low Value Payment Instrument that cannot be stopped or prevented from being used. Despite this agreement, the Payment Service Provider must always make sure that users have a way to notify them if their payment instrument is lost, stolen, misused, or used without permission. This means that even if some rules are skipped, the provider still has to keep a system in place for users to report problems, ensuring safety and protection against unauthorized use as required [#TGT:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a] and permitted [#SRC:1db4fdad-1fa0-4aae-ad68-56d8705902d9].

In terms of user notifications, the Payment Service Provider must ensure that the Framework Contract includes information about how the Payment Service User should notify the provider of any unauthorised or incorrectly initiated or executed Payment Transactions, as per Rule 19.17.1 [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. Additionally, the contract should describe the secure procedure by which the Payment Service Provider will contact the Payment Service User in the event of suspected or actual fraud or security threats [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. These provisions ensure that even when certain rules are waived, there are still mechanisms in place to protect the interests of the Payment Service User.

question: Under what circumstances is a Payment Service Provider not obligated to notify the Payment Service User of a refusal to execute a Payment Order, and what are the implications for Low Value Payment Instruments?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider is generally required to notify the Payment Service User at the earliest opportunity when refusing to execute a Payment Order, including providing reasons for the refusal and any procedures for correcting errors. However, in the specific case of a Payment Order relating to a Low Value Payment Instrument, the provider is not required to notify the user of the refusal if the non-execution is apparent from the context. This exception means that for Low Value Payment Instruments, the usual obligation to inform the user does not apply if the reason for refusal is clear without notification. This can streamline the process for low-value transactions, reducing administrative burdens on the provider while still maintaining transparency where necessary. The Payer also cannot revoke the Payment Order after it has been transmitted or consented to, and different execution periods may apply, further distinguishing these transactions from standard procedures [#SRC:a0213781-cf1e-47ae-befc-8e10afd8e60d] and [#TGT:7c2360b7-d85f-4ec3-97e2-e91cb6e4ae40].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider is not obligated to notify the Payment Service User of a refusal to execute a Payment Order when it relates to a Low Value Payment Instrument, provided that the non-execution is apparent from the context. This is an exception to the general rule that requires notification of refusal and the reasons for such refusal, as outlined in Rule 19.14.2(1) [#P:a0213781-cf1e-47ae-befc-8e10afd8e60d]. In the case of Low Value Payment Instruments, the Payer is also restricted from revoking the Payment Order after it has been transmitted or consent has been given to execute the Payment Transaction to the Payee [#P:a0213781-cf1e-47ae-befc-8e10afd8e60d]. Additionally, execution periods other than those typically provided may apply to these transactions [#P:a0213781-cf1e-47ae-befc-8e10afd8e60d]. This exception is designed to streamline the process for low value transactions, reducing the administrative burden on Payment Service Providers while maintaining efficiency in processing such payments.

question: Under what conditions may a Payment Service User and Provider agree to alter the notification period for unauthorised transactions, and what must the User do to ensure entitlement to redress?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User and its Payment Service Provider may agree in writing to apply a different time period for notifying unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions, provided the User is not a Natural Person. However, to be entitled to redress, the Payment Service User must notify its Payment Service Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date upon becoming aware of the issue. This agreement on a different time period does not negate the obligation for timely notification to secure redress, as required [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] and permitted [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297].
rag_answer: A Payment Service User and Provider may agree to alter the notification period for unauthorised transactions if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person. This agreement must be in writing, and it allows the parties to set a different time period for notifying unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions, diverging from the standard requirement of notifying without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. To ensure entitlement to redress, the Payment Service User must notify the Payment Service Provider of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction without undue delay, and in any event, within the agreed time period if it differs from the standard twelve months [#P:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]. If the Payment Service Provider fails to provide or make available information concerning the Payment Transaction as required, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress even if they fail to notify within the specified time period [#P:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4]. This ensures that the Payment Service User's rights to redress are protected under the specified conditions.

question: If a Payment Service User and Provider agree on a different time for reporting issues, what must the User still do to get redress?
gold_answer: Even if a Payment Service User and its Provider agree on a different time period for reporting unauthorised or incorrect transactions, the User must still notify the Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date to be entitled to redress. This agreement is only possible if the User is not a Natural Person. The User's obligation to report promptly remains crucial to secure redress, as required [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] and permitted [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297].
rag_answer: To obtain redress, a Payment Service User must ensure that the Payment Service Provider has failed to provide or make available information concerning the Payment Transaction as required by Section 19.5, even if the User has agreed to a different time period for reporting issues. This entitlement to redress is maintained regardless of the User's failure to notify the Provider within the agreed time period stated in Rule 19.17.1. [#P:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4] Additionally, the User and Provider may agree in writing to modify the time period for reporting unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transactions, but this does not affect the User's right to redress if the Provider fails in its duty to provide necessary transaction information. [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297] It is crucial for the User to document any such agreements and ensure that the Provider's obligations under Section 19.5 are clearly understood and adhered to, as this forms the basis for any claim to redress.

question: Under what circumstances must a Payment Service User notify their Payment Service Provider to be entitled to redress, and how does the failure of the Payment Service Provider to provide information affect this requirement?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User is entitled to redress under this Chapter only if it notifies its Payment Service Provider without undue delay, and in any event no later than twelve months after the debit date, on becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction. However, if the Payment Service Provider has failed to provide or make available the required information concerning the Payment Transaction, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress even if it has not notified the Payment Service Provider within the specified time period. This exception ensures that the Payment Service User's right to redress is preserved despite any lapses in notification, provided the failure to notify is due to the Payment Service Provider's omission in providing necessary transaction information [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] as required [#SRC:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4].
rag_answer: A Payment Service User must notify their Payment Service Provider without undue delay, and no later than twelve months after the debit date, upon becoming aware of any unauthorized or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction to be entitled to redress. This notification is a key precondition for seeking redress under the relevant rules. [#P:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] However, if the Payment Service Provider fails to provide or make available the required information concerning the Payment Transaction as stipulated, the Payment Service User retains the right to redress even if they have not notified the Payment Service Provider within the specified time frame. [#P:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4] This exception underscores the obligation of the Payment Service Provider to ensure that all necessary information is communicated to the Payment Service User, which includes details such as the unique identifier for the Payment Order, execution time, applicable charges, and exchange rates. [#P:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55] Therefore, while timely notification by the Payment Service User is generally required, the failure of the Payment Service Provider to fulfill its informational duties can override this requirement, allowing the user to seek redress regardless of the notification timeline.

question: When can a Payment Service User get redress if they don't notify their Payment Service Provider in time, and what happens if the provider didn't give transaction info?
gold_answer: A Payment Service User is entitled to redress under this Chapter only if it notifies its Payment Service Provider without undue delay, and in any event no later than twelve months after the debit date, on becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction. However, if the Payment Service Provider has failed to provide or make available the required information concerning the Payment Transaction, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress even if it has not notified the Payment Service Provider within the specified time period. This exception ensures that the Payment Service User's right to redress is preserved despite any lapses in notification, provided the failure to notify is due to the Payment Service Provider's omission in providing necessary transaction information [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] as required [#SRC:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4].
rag_answer: A Payment Service User can obtain redress even if they fail to notify their Payment Service Provider within the stipulated time if the provider did not provide or make available the necessary information concerning the Payment Transaction. Normally, a Payment Service User must notify their provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date upon becoming aware of any unauthorized or incorrectly executed Payment Transaction to be entitled to redress [#P:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]. However, if the Payment Service Provider fails to provide the required transaction information as per Section 19.5, the user retains the right to redress despite not meeting the notification deadline [#P:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4]. This exception ensures that users are not penalized for the provider's failure to fulfill their informational obligations.

question: When does a Payment Service Provider have to refund an unauthorised Payment Transaction, and what must a Payment Service User do to get redress?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider must refund an unauthorised Payment Transaction and, if needed, restore the account to its original state if the transaction wasn't authorised properly. For a Payment Service User to get redress, they must inform their Payment Service Provider quickly after noticing the unauthorised transaction. This must be done within twelve months from the date the transaction was debited. These rules ensure that both the provider and the user follow specific steps and timelines to resolve issues with unauthorised transactions, providing a clear framework for handling such situations [#TGT:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd] as required [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider is obligated to refund an unauthorised Payment Transaction if it was not authorised in accordance with Rule 19.10.1. The provider must refund the amount of the unauthorised transaction to the Payer and, where applicable, restore the debited Payment Account to its original state as if the unauthorised transaction had not occurred [#P:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a]. For a Payment Service User to obtain redress, they must notify their Payment Service Provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date upon becoming aware of the unauthorised or incorrectly executed transaction [#P:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]. However, if the Payment Service Provider has failed to provide or make available information concerning the transaction as required, the user is entitled to redress even if they did not notify the provider within the specified time frame [#P:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4]. Additionally, if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, they may agree in writing with the provider that certain rules, including those related to requests for refunds, do not apply [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297].

question: Under what circumstances may the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider agree to modify the applicability of certain rules, and what obligations does the Payment Service Provider have if they fail to provide required transaction information?
gold_answer: The Payment Service User, when not a Natural Person, and the Payment Service Provider may agree in writing to modify the applicability of specific rules, such as those concerning charges for information, withdrawal of consent, and requests for refunds. This agreement allows them to bypass certain standard rules, including those related to unauthorised or incorrectly executed transactions, by setting different terms. However, if the Payment Service Provider fails to provide or make available the necessary information concerning a Payment Transaction as required, the Payment Service User retains the right to seek redress under the applicable rules. This entitlement to redress remains valid even if the Payment Service User has not notified the Payment Service Provider within the designated time period stated in the rules. This ensures that the Payment Service User's rights are protected despite any agreed modifications to the standard rules [#TGT:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4] and permitted agreements [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297].
rag_answer: The Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider may agree to modify the applicability of certain rules, particularly in the context of Low-Value Payment Instruments. In such cases, the Payment Service Provider is only required to provide the Payer with information about the main characteristics of the Payment Service, such as how the Payment Instrument can be used, the Payer's liability, charges levied, and any other material information needed for an informed decision. Additionally, the Payment Service Provider must indicate where the general information concerning the Framework Contract is made available in an easily accessible manner [#P:419d782f-001f-4e45-bcc1-903132223a21]. If the Payment Service Provider fails to provide or make available the required transaction information as stipulated in Section 19.5, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress under the Rules in this Chapter, even if they have not notified the Payment Service Provider within the specified time period [#P:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4]. This ensures that the Payment Service User's rights are protected despite any lapses in notification.

question: When can the Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider decide to change some rules, and what happens if the Provider doesn't give the right transaction info?
gold_answer: The Payment Service User, if they are not a Natural Person, and the Payment Service Provider can agree in writing to change certain rules. These rules include those about charges for information, consent withdrawal, and refund requests. They can also agree on different time periods for dealing with unauthorised or incorrect transactions. However, if the Payment Service Provider does not provide the necessary transaction information, the Payment Service User can still seek compensation under the rules. This right to compensation is valid even if the Payment Service User did not notify the Payment Service Provider within the usual time limits. This ensures that the Payment Service User's rights are protected, even if they have agreed to change some rules with the Provider [#TGT:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4] and have the permission to do so [#SRC:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297].
rag_answer: The Payment Service User and the Payment Service Provider can agree to change some rules within a Framework Contract if the contract allows for unilateral changes by the Provider, provided the User does not object before the changes take effect. In such cases, the Provider must inform the User that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes unless they notify otherwise, and that they have the right to terminate the contract without charge before the changes take effect [#P:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. If the Payment Service Provider fails to provide or make available the required transaction information, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress under the applicable rules, even if they did not notify the Provider within the specified time period [#P:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4]. This ensures that the User's rights are protected despite any procedural lapses by the Provider.

question: Under what circumstances must a Payment Service Provider refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction, and when is the Payment Service User entitled to redress despite not notifying within the specified time period?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider is obligated to refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer and, if applicable, restore the debited Payment Account to its original state if the transaction was not authorised as per the relevant rules. This obligation arises when the Payment Service Provider has executed a Payment Transaction without proper authorisation. Concurrently, the Payment Service User is entitled to seek redress even if they have not notified the Payment Service Provider within the stipulated time frame, provided the Payment Service Provider has failed to furnish or make available the necessary information concerning the Payment Transaction as required. This entitlement to redress is applicable under the rules of the chapter, ensuring that the Payment Service User's rights are protected despite any lapse in notification, as long as the Payment Service Provider's informational obligations have not been met [#TGT:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4] and permitted [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider must refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction if the Payment Service User notifies the provider without undue delay and no later than twelve months after the debit date upon becoming aware of the unauthorised transaction [#P:9e69f77e-6b54-411e-bb70-41a02ee9e6cd]. However, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress even if they fail to notify within this specified time period if the Payment Service Provider did not provide or make available the necessary information concerning the Payment Transaction as required [#P:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4]. Additionally, the Payment Service Provider is obligated to ensure that appropriate means are available at all times for the Payment Service User to report the loss, theft, misappropriation, or unauthorised use of the Payment Instrument [#P:9b652a81-4dfa-4909-b738-a9285f01f41a]. In cases where the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the parties may agree in writing to different terms, including a different time period for reporting unauthorised or incorrectly executed transactions [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. These provisions ensure that users have a clear path to redress while also outlining the responsibilities of the Payment Service Provider.

question: When does a Payment Service Provider have to refund an unauthorised payment, and when can a Payment Service User get redress even if they didn't notify in time?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider must refund the amount of an unauthorised Payment Transaction to the Payer and, if needed, return the Payment Account to its original state if the transaction was not properly authorised. This is required when the Payment Service Provider has executed a transaction without the necessary authorisation. At the same time, a Payment Service User can still get redress even if they didn't notify the Payment Service Provider within the required time. This is possible if the Payment Service Provider didn't provide or make available the required information about the Payment Transaction. In such cases, the Payment Service User's right to redress is protected under the rules, ensuring they can seek compensation despite any delay in notification, as long as the Payment Service Provider has not fulfilled its informational duties [#TGT:82c7349e-fc45-46c6-adc3-d75ea1094bd4] and permitted [#SRC:49dd4b51-276a-406c-ab4c-17a9797a7a7a].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider is obligated to refund an unauthorised payment transaction when it was not authorised in accordance with Rule 19.10.1. In such cases, the provider must refund the amount of the unauthorised transaction to the payer and, where applicable, restore the debited payment account to the state it would have been in had the unauthorised transaction not occurred [#P:49dd4b51]. For a Payment Service User to be entitled to redress, they must notify their Payment Service Provider without undue delay, and no later than twelve months after the debit date, upon becoming aware of any unauthorised or incorrectly executed payment transaction [#P:9e69f77e]. However, if the Payment Service Provider fails to provide or make available information concerning the payment transaction as required, the Payment Service User is entitled to redress even if they did not notify the provider within the specified time period [#P:82c7349e]. This ensures that users are protected in cases where they are not adequately informed by their providers, maintaining fairness in the redress process.

question: What details must be in a Framework Contract between a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User, and when must more information be given if the user asks?
gold_answer: A Framework Contract between a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User must include various details unless both parties agree otherwise in writing. These details cover the provider's information, the service's main features, charges, communication methods, safety measures, contract changes, and dispute resolution options. If the service involves Stored Value, redemption conditions must also be included. If the Payment Service User asks for more information during the contract, the provider must give the specified details and any other contract terms. This ensures users get all needed information as required [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] and allowed [#SRC:297c1b5c-a066-4f82-b626-7572c7d5de26].
rag_answer: A Framework Contract between a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User must include detailed information about the provider, the service, charges, communication, safeguards, contract changes, and redress mechanisms. Specifically, it must cover the provider's name, contact details, and regulatory information; a description of the payment service and necessary identifiers; consent procedures; execution times; spending limits; charges and exchange rates; communication methods; security measures; liability terms; contract duration and termination rights; applicable law and dispute resolution; and conditions for stored value redemption, if applicable [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. This information must be provided before the user is bound by the contract [#P:1c9435a6-bd7b-44dd-85e5-3c16cba75646]. If the user requests additional information beyond what is required, more frequent provision, or communication through different means, the provider and user may agree on charges for such requests [#P:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7].

question: What must a Payment Service Provider include in a Framework Contract, and how soon must they tell the Payment Service User about changes?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider has to include a lot of important details in a Framework Contract. This includes information about themselves, like their name and contact details, and about the payment service, such as how it works and any charges. They also need to explain how they will communicate with the Payment Service User and what to do if something goes wrong. If there are any changes to these details, the provider must inform the Payment Service User at least two months before the changes happen. This rule helps ensure that the Payment Service User knows what's going on and can prepare for any changes. However, if both the provider and the user agree in writing, they might be able to change this timing. This is especially important when the user is not a Natural Person, meaning it's a business or organization [#SRC:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] and [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider must include specific information in a Framework Contract and notify the Payment Service User about changes in a timely manner. The Framework Contract must contain details about the Payment Service Provider, such as its name, address, and contact details in ADGM, as well as information about the Payment Service, including its main characteristics and execution times [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. It should also cover charges, exchange rates, communication methods, safeguards, corrective measures, and conditions for changes and termination of the contract [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. Before the Payment Service User is bound by the Framework Contract, the Payment Service Provider must provide this information [#P:1c9435a6-bd7b-44dd-85e5-3c16cba75646]. If changes to the contract are proposed, the Payment Service Provider must inform the Payment Service User that they will be deemed to have accepted the changes unless they notify otherwise before the changes take effect. The user also has the right to terminate the contract without charge before the changes are enforced [#P:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. This ensures transparency and allows the Payment Service User to make informed decisions regarding their contractual obligations.

question: When can a Payment Service Provider change exchange rates right away, and what must they include about exchange rates in the contract?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider can change exchange rates right away and without telling the Payment Service User if the contract allows it and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information given to the user. The contract must include details about the exchange rates that will be used or how to calculate them if Reference Exchange Rates are used. It should also cover how changes in these rates will be applied and what information will be provided about such changes, unless a different agreement is made in writing between the Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User who is not a Natural Person, as required [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] and permitted [#SRC:d1ff305e-8ed4-430f-a3ca-684f0dc00939].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider can change exchange rates immediately and without notice if such a right is agreed upon in the Framework Contract and the changes are based on the Reference Exchange Rate information provided to the Payment Service User, or if the changes are more favorable to the Payment Service User [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] [#P:d1ff305e-8ed4-430f-a3ca-684f0dc00939]. The Framework Contract must include details of all charges payable by the Payment Service User, including a breakdown of amounts, and where relevant, details of the exchange rates to be applied or the method of calculating the relevant date for determining such Reference Exchange Rates [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. Additionally, if agreed, the contract should cover the application of changes in Reference Exchange Rates and the information requirements relating to any such changes [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. This ensures transparency and clarity for the Payment Service User regarding potential fluctuations in exchange rates and associated costs.

question: What information must a Payment Service Provider include in a Framework Contract with a Payment Service User, and what must be provided or made available before the Payment Service User is bound by the Single Payment Service Contract?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider is required to include specific information in a Framework Contract with a Payment Service User, unless otherwise agreed in writing and the user is not a Natural Person. This includes details about the Payment Service Provider, the Payment Service, charges, exchange rates, communication methods, safeguards, corrective measures, contract changes, termination, and redress options. Concurrently, before a Payment Service User is bound by a Single Payment Service Contract, the provider must supply or make available information such as the unique identifier for initiating a Payment Order, execution time, applicable charges, and relevant exchange rates. This ensures the user is fully informed about the service terms and conditions, facilitating transparency and compliance with regulatory requirements [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] and permitted [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55].
rag_answer: A Payment Service Provider must include specific information in a Framework Contract with a Payment Service User and provide certain details before the user is bound by a Single Payment Service Contract. The Framework Contract must encompass details about the Payment Service Provider, such as its name, address, and regulatory information, as well as a description of the main characteristics of the Payment Service, including the necessary information or unique identifier for initiating and executing a Payment Order [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. It should also cover charges, exchange rates, communication methods, safeguards, corrective measures, contract changes, termination terms, and redress options [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. Before a Payment Service User is bound by a Single Payment Service Contract, the provider must supply or make available information such as the unique identifier for initiating a Payment Order, the maximum execution time, applicable charges, and the exchange rate if relevant [#P:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]. This ensures that the Payment Service User is fully informed of the terms and conditions before entering into the contract.

question: What must a Payment Service Provider give to a Payment Service User before they agree to a Single Payment Service Contract, and what should be in the Framework Contract?
gold_answer: Before a Payment Service User agrees to a Single Payment Service Contract, the Payment Service Provider must give them important details like the unique identifier needed for a Payment Order, how long the service will take, any charges, and exchange rates. This helps the user understand what they are agreeing to. In a Framework Contract, the provider must include information about themselves, the service, charges, communication methods, and what happens if something goes wrong. They also need to explain how the contract can change or end, and how disputes can be resolved. This is required unless the provider and user, who is not a Natural Person, agree otherwise in writing. These steps ensure that users have all the necessary information to make informed decisions [#TGT:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b] and permitted [#SRC:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55].
rag_answer: Before a Payment Service User agrees to a Single Payment Service Contract, a Payment Service Provider must provide specific information, and the Framework Contract must include detailed provisions. For a Single Payment Service Contract, the Payment Service Provider must give the Payment Service User information such as the unique identifier needed to initiate or execute a Payment Order, the maximum execution time, applicable charges and their breakdown, the actual or Reference Exchange Rate, and relevant information specified in Rule 19.2.1 [#P:8dd39e9b-0a4b-4ecc-a10e-960de38fea55]. The Framework Contract must include comprehensive details about the Payment Service Provider, the Payment Service, charges and exchange rates, communication methods, safeguards and corrective measures, changes and termination terms, redress options, and conditions for Stored Value redemption if applicable [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. This information must be provided before the Payment Service User is bound by the Framework Contract [#P:1c9435a6-bd7b-44dd-85e5-3c16cba75646]. This ensures that the Payment Service User is fully informed and can make an educated decision before entering into the contract.

question: Under what conditions may a Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User agree on charges for additional information, and what limitations are imposed on these charges?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider and a Payment Service User may agree on charges for information that is additional to the standard requirements, provided more frequently than specified, or transmitted through alternative communication methods. However, any charges imposed must not exceed the actual costs incurred by the Payment Service Provider in providing such information. This ensures that while there is flexibility in agreeing to additional services, the charges remain fair and reflective of actual expenses. The agreement on charges is contingent upon the information being requested by the Payment Service User and falling outside the standard provisions. This regulatory framework balances the need for additional information with cost transparency and fairness, ensuring that users are not overcharged for services beyond the standard requirements [#SRC:0ddfb32a-c23e-4da9-af5e-d04b51f92c41] [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7].

The agreement on such charges is subject to the mutual consent of both parties, and the charges must be clearly detailed in the Framework Contract, including a breakdown of the amounts if applicable [#P:08c0ad25-70d0-4613-863a-43b760cfd83b]. Additionally, if the Payment Service User is not a Natural Person, the parties may agree in writing that the rules concerning charges for information do not apply, allowing for further flexibility in their agreement [#P:95fa60a1-7e5a-4d8c-ad0f-194df6db4297]. This ensures that both parties have a clear understanding of any additional costs associated with the provision of information beyond the standard requirements.

question: When can a Payment Service Provider charge for extra information, and what limits are there on these charges?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider can charge for extra information if the Payment Service User asks for it and it is not part of the usual information provided. This can happen if the information is more than what is normally required, is given more often than usual, or is sent in a different way than agreed in the contract. However, the charges for this extra information must not be more than what it actually costs the provider to give it. This means that while users can request and agree to pay for additional services, the charges must be fair and only cover the actual costs of providing the information. This ensures users are not overcharged for services beyond the standard offerings [#SRC:0ddfb32a-c23e-4da9-af5e-d04b51f92c41] [#TGT:18f42ca0-235a-47ac-9e8c-47bd6dd631d7].

question: When can the Payment Service Provider and User agree on extra charges for information if the User isn't a Natural Person?

question: What actions must a Payment Service Provider take when proposing unilateral changes to a Framework Contract, and what are the notification requirements for these changes?
gold_answer: When a Payment Service Provider intends to make unilateral changes to a Framework Contract, it must inform the Payment Service User that the changes will be deemed accepted unless the user notifies otherwise before the changes take effect. Additionally, the Payment Service Provider must inform the user of their right to terminate the contract without charge before the changes are implemented. Furthermore, the Payment Service Provider is obligated to provide the proposed changes to the Payment Service User no later than two months before the changes are scheduled to take effect. This ensures that the user has adequate time to consider the changes and exercise their rights as required [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] and permitted [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1].
rag_answer: When a Payment Service Provider proposes unilateral changes to a Framework Contract, they must adhere to specific notification requirements to ensure compliance. Firstly, the Payment Service Provider must provide the Payment Service User with the proposed changes no later than two months before the changes are set to take effect [#P:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5]. Additionally, the Payment Service Provider must inform the Payment Service User that if they do not notify the provider to the contrary before the proposed date of entry into force, they will be deemed to have accepted the changes [#P:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. Furthermore, the Payment Service User must be informed of their right to terminate the Framework Contract without charge at any time before the proposed date of the changes' entry into force [#P:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1]. These steps ensure that the Payment Service User is adequately informed and has the opportunity to respond or terminate the contract if they do not agree with the proposed changes.

question: What must a Payment Service Provider do when it wants to change a Framework Contract, and how soon must it tell the Payment Service User?
gold_answer: A Payment Service Provider must tell the Payment Service User about any changes to a Framework Contract at least two months before they start. The user also has the right to cancel the contract without any fees before the changes are enforced. This process ensures that the user is fully informed and can make decisions accordingly, as required [#TGT:5034d490-7144-4672-b527-0854d50aeec5] and permitted [#SRC:3f0b9767-ce03-4986-bf5f-630548e2a5e1].
